item.title: About
item.dc:creator: amysgurumis
item.content:encoded: Hello! My name is Amy. I'm a technical writer living in Ottawa, Canada. In my spare time, I love to crochet and design amigurumis. It all started the summer I turned thirteen. My cousin Katie and I found a book of amigurumi patterns in a used book store. We bought the book to share and each crocheted our first stuffed animal. I made a pig and Katie made a hippo. I cringe when I look at this overstuffed and scraggly little pig, but I keep him for sentimental value. I spent several months following my favourite patterns byAna Paula Rimoli. Then I started designing my own. My first project was a terrifying Peter Rabbit. His thighs are bigger than his head, and I tended to over stuff. But I have progressed since Peter. Here is my own pig design crocheted up, a big improvement on my first pig. In October 2012 and February 2013, I participated as a vendor in the Ontario Valley Crafts & Collectiblesshow. I've also designedcrocheted versions of Chummy, Sister Bernadette, and Shelaghfrom Call the Midwife. Trixie was featured on the BBC One Show in January 2015, and all three were featured in the January 2017 Let's Knit Magazine! If you have a favourite character you'd like to see crocheted, contact me and I'd love to make that happen. Thanks for visiting Amy's Gurumis!

item.title: Call the Crocheted Chummy!
item.dc:creator: amysgurumis
item.content:encoded: My obsession with Call the Midwife has entered the ultimate phase: the amigurumifiying of one of my favourite characters...Chummy! She's just tickety-boo and marvelous, weighs about the size of a turkey, and I refer to her as "little bean". I started crocheting her over a month ago, and since I work nights now, it was a long process. Plenty of trial and error, lots of sweat (the weather's been humid and humidity doesn't mix well with aluminum crochet hooks), too many trips to Michaels, a request for my wonderful cousins Katie and Julia to loan me a spiffing pair of American Girl doll glasses, and combing through Call the Midwife pictures to make sure I chose yarn that was as close to the real-life colours as possible have all culminated in myCamilla Fortescue-Cholmeley-Browne amigurumi. It was a bit of a scrape, but she's finished and I couldn't be more pleased. Listening to the Call the Midwife soundtrack and re watching episodes from the first two seasons passed the time while I crocheted, even when I had to redo the blue uniform for the third time to make it fit just right.(Maybe it would have been preferable to make it out of crimplene instead of Snuggly Wuggly acrylic?). And of course, I will have to make another uniform in eau-de-nil, I'm sure she'd look a picture in that! I've included photos of my notes,which will hopefully be written up into a proper pattern someday. Even when I'd completed her, it couldn't be as simple as taking pictures and posting them. The photo that turned out best was one where I'd forgotten to include the delivery bag, so I called upon the generous services of my brother. He photoshopped the delivery bag into the photo for me and did a fantastic job. Bravo Mitch! (Except we both came to the conclusion that the original picture looked better, even without the delivery bag, but I had to give him credit for wasting his evening). Hope all of you Call the Midwife fans enjoy these pictures of Chummy while you wait eagerly for series 3! I'm sure you'd all agree that she's the sort of amigurumi a chap's mother would like.

item.title: May 2016: My 5 Favourite Etsy Shops
item.dc:creator: amysgurumis
item.content:encoded:
1.LuvlyGurumi

This shop has been a favourite of mine for years. I've purchased nearly every LuvlyGurumi pattern. The placement of the safety eyes and mouth designs are perfect. The patterns are clear, well written, and include photos. My personal favourite is the monkey with his adorable hood and banana.I'm a huge fan of using the same yarn for all of my patterns (I use Bernat Handicrafter Cotton for mine) and this shop uses Vanna's Choice, which has a great range of colours for amigurumi.

2.Mary Jane's Tea Room

This shop is unbelievably cute, especially the Little Yarn Dolls pattern. I purchased Method 2, which is knit flat and then seamed because I'm not comfortable using circular needles just yet. I love that this shop offers both a flat and circular version of the same pattern!

3.Dolly Time

Another knitted toy shop, and the dolls are so sweet! A couple of years ago I knit a puppet from this shop:Ruby and Rose Hand Puppets. It was easy to follow even though I'm not an experienced knitter, and turned out just like the picture. I'm excited to try out more Dolly Time patterns.

4.Bubbles and Bongo

This is a shop I only recently discovered. I fell in love with the photography! I've purchasedPippa the Pig, and I'll post a picture once I've crocheted her!

5.hookabee

It's so exciting to discover other Canadian amigurumi shops! I've attempted crocheting in the back loops only, but never designed a toy I'm happy with using this method. Hookabee has inspired me to give it another go!I've purchased the Narwhal pattern and can't wait to start crocheting!

item.title: Amigurumi for Beginners
item.dc:creator: amysgurumis
item.content:encoded: Ten of my patterns have been published in a bookazine by Future Publishing! Theytech-edited the patterns and photographed the toys!Jen Neal, the Production Editor, was wonderful to work with, and she sent me these screenshots below: Check out the bookazine (Amigurumi for Beginners) on Future Publishing's website.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Dear Amy, I'm having a problem with another pattern in the Amigurumi for Beginners 'zine. (Not one of yours but you're the only human I've been able to find in relation to this publication.). I'm trying to make Pearl the Dolfin page 112. No matter what I do, the center starting round ends up twisted almost 45 degrees. Also, the counts in the rounds are off and I've had to ignore those. I'm losing my mind. I'm on the verge of dragging out some graph paper and attempting to rewrite the pattern myself. But being a novice, I fear I'll only make more frustration for myself. Can you please offer me any advice? I'd be so grateful. Thank you. Deborah

Hi, your patterns are gorgeous and I want to make them all! Im trying to track down a copy of the bookazine but cannot find it anywhere! Do you happen to know of any retailers where I could buy a copy? Thank you! x

item.title: Amigurumi design with Kathleen
item.dc:creator: amysgurumis
item.content:encoded: Back today to share some amigurumiinspiration! Kathleen is a talented crocheter. She made the amigurumi below by following theLittle Bunny pattern. Kathleen contacted me on Etsy andmade a great request for the Little Bunny's wardrobe: open backed shirts and dresses so the clothing is easier to take on and off (you don't have to pull them over the bunny's big head!). I wrote up a patternfor an open backed shirt, and Kathleen cleverly adapted the instructions to several outfits that you can see below. Her designs are so fun and creative! I'm looking forward to trying this out with different bunny outfits myself, and I'mthankful for Kathleen taking the initiative on this one! It's great to have crocheters findimprovementsthat the designer might not think of herself, so thank you Kathleen! Click here to download the open-backed shirt pattern. Click here to purchase the little bunny pattern. Click here to download the little bunny's wardrobe pattern. Have a great weekend, and happy crocheting!

item.title: Sue - 2018-04-15 23:49:18
item.content:encoded:
Hello,
First of all, I just wanted to say how much I love your blog. My Aunt once gave me a beautiful amigurumi doll, holding a bouquet of flowers. She had a wee hat on her head. She was a true Irish lass, made in Ireland. I am not sure if I still have the dolly, but I remember it with fondness.
Second, I was wondering if you would find old amigurumi patterns useful? I believe I have a few that belonged to my Aunt. You might find them inspiring.
Sincerely,
Sue Faulkner <!--more--> AUTHOR: Sue AUTHOR EMAIL: irishcanadianauthor@gmail.com AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: [] Contact IP: 184.94.182.58 Array ( [1_Name] => Sue [2_Email] => irishcanadianauthor@gmail.com [3_Website] => [4_Comment] => Hello,

Second, I was wondering if you would find old amigurumi patterns useful? I believe I have a few that belonged to my Aunt. You might find them inspiring.
Sincerely,
Sue Faulkner )

item.title: Sharon Pecinovsky - 2018-06-27 16:06:00
item.content:encoded: I have bought Create with Crochet and I am in the process of making the proud lion. Im having issues with mane edging using color 3, ch 69. Row 1: dc into 2nd ch from hook, dc to end, turn. (48 sits). How can that be 48 stitches it should 68 stitches. Or is it a typo. Also it says for nose and mouth use the templates below. There arent any templates on all of the pages. Could you send me a copy of templates? <!--more--> AUTHOR: Sharon Pecinovsky AUTHOR EMAIL: twinii2000@gmail.com AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: [] Contact IP: 68.228.205.142 Array ( [1_Name] => Sharon Pecinovsky [2_Email] => twinii2000@gmail.com [3_Website] => [4_Comment] => I have bought Create with Crochet and I am in the process of making the proud lion. item.title: Shannon - 2018-12-11 18:25:52
item.content:encoded: hello, I am having difficulty with the American Girl Doll Shoes crochet pattern in that on R5, the dc10 stitches are not lining up to be at what I would assume should be to the front of the toe. I don't know what I'm doing wrong. one pair was kinda sorta at the toe, others were at the side??? It may have to do right from the start with the R1 instruction where you continue down the other side of the ch and sc5 or where to begin the R2 increasing stitches but I just can't figure out where I'm going wrong and I can't tell by the pictures on the pattern. any insight you could offer I'd be very grateful for as I'm finding this quite frustrating as I don't want to give up on this.. thank you ps I'm not a beginner crocheter <!--more--> AUTHOR: Shannon AUTHOR EMAIL: nichol24@telus.net AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: [] Contact IP: 23.16.183.46 Array ( [1_Name] => Shannon [2_Email] => nichol24@telus.net [3_Website] => [4_Comment] => hello, I am having difficulty with the American Girl Doll Shoes crochet pattern in that on R5, the dc10 stitches are not lining up to be at what I would assume should be to the front of the toe. I don't know what I'm doing wrong. one pair was kinda sorta at the toe, others were at the side??? It may have to do right from the start with the R1 instruction where you continue down the other side of the ch and sc5 or where to begin the R2 increasing stitches but I just can't figure out where I'm going wrong and I can't tell by the pictures on the pattern. any insight you could offer I'd be very grateful for as I'm finding this quite frustrating as I don't want to give up on this.. thank you ps I'm not a beginner crocheter [entry_title] => Contact [entry_permalink] => https://amysgurumis.wordpress.com/contact/ [feedback_id] => f385ea44a7169e9956d073d56bbcc317 )

a:2:{s:2:"to";a:1:{i:0;s:37:""amysgurumis" ";}s:7:"message";s:1153:" Name: Shannon

Website:

Comment: hello, I am having difficulty with the American Girl Doll Shoes crochet pattern in that on R5, the dc10 stitches are not lining up to be at what I would assume should be to the front of the toe. I don't know what I'm doing wrong. one pair was kinda sorta at the toe, others were at the side??? It may have to do right from the start with the R1 instruction where you continue down the other side of the ch and sc5 or where to begin the R2 increasing stitches but I just can't figure out where I'm going wrong and I can't tell by the pictures on the pattern. any insight you could offer I'd be very grateful for as I'm finding this quite frustrating as I don't want to give up on this.. thank you
ps I'm not a beginner crocheter
